text: Subimal Goswami (15 January 1938 – 30 April 2020), commonly known by his nickname Chuni Goswami, was an Indian international footballer and first class cricketer. He was born in Kishoreganj District, Bangladesh. He played 30 international matches representing India and scored 9 times for the team. He played Ranji Trophy for Bengal, captainingFormer Bengal captain Chuni Goswami dies aged 82 ESPNcricinfo his team to the final of the tournament in 1971–72. Goswami died on 30 April 2020 in Kolkata of cardiac arrest, aged 82. ==Football== ===Career statistics=== ====International statistics==== Chuni Goswami played in 30 FIFA "A" international matches having scored 9 times for the National team. India national team India national team India national team Year Apps Goals 1958 5 2 1959 6 1 1960 3 0 1961 3 0 1962 5 3 1964 8 3 Total 30 9 ====International goals==== Date Venue Opponent Score Result Competition Goals 26 May 1958 Korakuen Velodrome, Tokyo 3–2 Won 1958 Asian Games 1 30 May 1958 Tokyo Football Stadium, Tokyo 5–2 Won 1958 Asian Games 1 11 December 1959 Maharaja's College Stadium, Kochi 3−1 Won 1960 AFC Asian Cup qualification 1 28 August 1962 Senayan Stadium, Jakarta 4–1 Won 1962 Asian Games 1 1 September 1962 Senayan Stadium, Jakarta 3–2 Won 1962 Asian Games 2 2 June 1964 Bloomfield Stadium, Tel Aviv 3–1 Won 1964 AFC Asian Cup 1 27 August 1964 Kuala Lumpur, Malaya 4–0 Won 1964 Merdeka Tournament 1 29 August 1964 Kuala Lumpur, Malaya 2–1 Won 1964 Merdeka Tournament 1 ===Honours=== Mohun Bagan *Durand Cup: 1959, 1960, 1963, 1964, 1965 *IFA Shield: 1960, 1961, 1962, 1967 *Rovers Cup: 1966 *Calcutta Football League: 1959, 1960, 1962, 1963, 1964, 1965 India *Asian Games Gold medal: 1962 *AFC Asian Cup runners-up: 1964 *Merdeka Tournament runner-up: 1964 Bengal * Santosh Trophy: 1955–56, 1958–59 Individual * Mohun Bagan Ratna Award: 2001 * Banga Bibhushan: 2013 Records *Top goal scorer of Calcutta Football League (with 145 goals) Accolades * Sportskeeda All time Indian Football XI ==Cricket career== Chuni Goswami made his first class debut for Bengal in the Ranji Trophy during the 1962–63 season. He was a right-handed batsman and a right-arm medium pace bowler. ==References== Category:1938 births Category:2020 deaths Category:Deaths from cardiac arrest Category:Indian footballers Category:Indian cricketers
